list_definition.definition: a mark or sign left by something

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: There were traces of egg on the plate
There’s still no trace of the missing child.
Traces of poison were found in the cup.

list_definition.definition: to follow or discover by means of clues, evidence etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The police have traced him to London
The source of the infection has not yet been traced.

list_definition.definition: to make a copy of (a picture etc) by putting transparent paper over it and drawing the outline etc

list_ex_of_english: The growth of the economy is traced over time, taking into account population growth, capital accumulation, and technical change.
Further, where deaths are recorded without precision, we do not always find a trace of these in the death register.
Indeed, we can, in fact, confidently trace hyper-rhoticity back to at least the eighteenth century.
The partial beam divergence values, one can calculate from the present geometry (distance of the source to the detector), and trace the spread.
Ultimately the origin of the discrepancies can be traced back in part to whether the centromeric and pericentromeric insertion sites are considered in the analysis.
Analytical precision is better than 0.5 % for major elements and 5 % for trace elements.
On closer viewing, the individual boards and the grain of the timber are revealed as traces of construction.
These traces themselves represent primary (bio)information about the original changeable environment.
